title: Punishment system is a flawed.
body: So I haven't been playing lol for months, and a few weeks ago came back and just now got a 14 day ban for flaming. I'll be the first one to admit that I am a toxic player who is easily capable of starting to insult people (calling them trash, mostly) when they make serious gameplay mistakes or personally attack me. Fine, I deserve a punishment. But does it have to be a 2 week ban and a perma ban sometime later? I know my temper won't change. Eventually someone will once again trigger me to the point where I get multiple reports and an autoban. But I never troll in any other way. I always (99% of time, at least) play to the best of my ability, never intentionally feed or ruin game in other way. So wouldn't a permanent chat ban/restriction will be a more fitting punishment for me? I would eagerly mute myself if there were such an option, most people communicate with pings nowadays anyway, words are no longer essential for efficient gameplay. I understand that I deserve a punishment, but I do strongly feel that this is the wrong one... You don't give a life sentence to a person who screams profanities on a street, after all.

14-day ban out of nowhere sounds like you were using slurs, which Riot explicitly has a zero-tolerance policy regarding. Gotta not do that.

Permanent chat bans were used in the long-past days of the Tribunal, but they tended to just result in other methods of trolling, so the practice was ended.
You're right, I did use one, didn't realize that it was a racial slur until you mentioned it, stupid of me.
You actually didn't have a direct 14-day ban. This is your 3rd penalty without changing your behavior, so it was escalated to a 14-day ban. 3 recent games were given as evidence.

Unfortunately it looks like the context of the OP is that he does not believe he can or is willing to change his behavior to match the requirements of the community.
"But does it have to be a 2 week ban and a perma ban sometime later? I know my temper won't change."
He's acknowledging that he is actively breaking the TOS repeatedly and is actually trying to change the punishment to fit the crime as he sees it to be. That's my impression.

Not everyone learns mistakes and betters themselves through the same punishments as others. This is all left to perception. Which it seems everyone has refused to acknowledge. All individual people, Learn and experience emotions different ways in such the way we handle them is all different. There are millions of players, Working in the field of children/adults I've seen that people HONESTLY DO NOT have complete control over their own person's. Which because they are online, they cannot be identified as such.

I don't agree with some of the method's that riot has come up with, I think there are better methods. Some more harsh, some not as harsh. But not my company to do as such with. But my main point, Generalized punishments, do NOT work. Honest truth.

In the future just know that you have to actually play games in order for the system to determine whether your behavior has changed or not, and this is intended so that griefers and would-be griefers can't just simply stop playing for an extended period of time and hope/expect that the system forgets about their behavior.

Bear in mind that this isn't a street though -- it's Riot's private servers, which they are letting you access.

I *would* ban someone who reliably screams profanities from my bar, restaurant, movie theater, golf course, or house. They've proven they can't behave themselves in my privately owned and operated area, and, as such, it is within my rights to tell them never to come back, and bar them from doing so if necessary.

Even if they're happily playing golf or sitting in their own booth, their behavior and the mood they create is enough to make them a negative influence on the environment. So even if you don't troll and you always play to win, there can still be valid justification for wanting you to either moderate your behavior or find another game to play.

Riot DID try an experiment where they simply silenced players. They found that it was largely unsuccessful, as players started finding other, more subtle ways to troll with such regularity that they discontinued the practice.

I understand this may work for you personally, but Riot needed a large-scale solution. I also believe (but have no confirmation) that they feel that if you cannot moderate your behavior enough to be trusted to talk to another player they simply do not want you around as part of the community.

Here I will have to respectfully disagree, as I firmly believe, that in every aspect of life, nothing should be generalized and as much as possible should be on case-by-case basis. That's how real life courts have worked for ages, after all. 

Second part of your idea also gives me some pause, as, in my experience, a great many people here will be malevolent without active cursing. People will threaten to report for almost every conceivable thing, are eager to gank up on who they assume will receive most reports, etc. If riot truly wanted to make a perfect community of hospitality, they failed miserably with this current system that encourages people to make threats, to seek moral high ground and to /allchat report this guy for "insert whatever". That is just my personal perspective though.

Does it, though? If you really think about, all it creates is a vicious cycle of aggression where everyone wants to get back at everyone for the most minor of slights. You say that part of system is working "at least" decently, yet in my experience, nearly in every match I've played in this season (around 100), someone wanted other people to report someone else, which itself, is a reportable offense, iirc. The truth is, if you look at history, tightening control _Never _worked out for the authority in the end. It doesn't work for governments, it doesn't work for corporations, it doesn't work for online communites. The more you tighten the screws, the less comfortable the people feel, the more unwarranted aggression arises. This may sound like a rant of a person trying to justify his poor behaviour, and maybe it is, but I remember LoL community 5 years ago as FAR more easy-going.

>  You don't give a life sentence to a person who screams profanities on a street, after all.

Totally agree, you don't.

But remember, you're not getting a life prison sentence. You're getting a game ban.  Be glad you're not getting a police citation, counseling and community service for screaming profanities through the street.

Lighten up on the rage a bit, k?  

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

May I just enquire about the intention behind this comment? Firstly, one shouldn't take comparisons or parallels at face value. Secondly, human psychology is an interesting thing, telling an agitated person something like "Lighten up on the rage a bit." will rarely, if ever have the desired effect.

The thing is, you would get a life sentence if those were the rules or laws established beforehand. You accepted the terms of use, you get punished according to those terms. 
"Section 2. Account Termination" and "Section 5. Code of Conduct" in the Terms of Use cover the rules you accepted and are violated to get the 14-day ban.
Look into unbinding your "enter" key. It should make it so you can't chat in game.

I guess I should try that, lol. Kinda wish riot would just make a self-mute option somewhere in profile settings, which would also make you immune to verbal abuse kind of reports. Wishful thinking though.

I am just gonna leave these forums and try to do what I came to lol to do - to play the game, not communicate, maybe unbinding "enter" will work for me in the long term.
